LISTSERV Web Interface 2.4.1 2015-03-11T20:31:03Z Oliver Hooker 2015-03-11T20:29:27+00:00 2015-03-11T20:29:27+00:00 Advancing in 'R' statistics course https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CLIMATE-CHANGE-IMPACTS;cae86342.1503 A repeat of the course titled 'ADVANCING IN R' has been scheduled for 30th November \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd 4th December 2015<br><br>This course will provide an introduction to model selection and simplification, mixed effects models, generalised linear models and non-linear models<br><br>The content is designed to bridge the gap between basic R coding and more advanced statistical modelling whilst providing an overview of the most frequently used approaches to analysing data. Young Lee 2015-02-27T16:37:58+00:00 2015-02-27T16:37:58+00:00 Reconsidering Sustainability: Interdisciplinary Perspectives from Asia https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CLIMATE-CHANGE-IMPACTS;1d408427.1502 Dear Colleague,<br><br>We are pleased to announce that the latest issue of Nature and Culture has recently been published by Berghahn Journals. The first issue of the tenth volume of this journal is devoted to reconsidering sustainability through interdisciplinary perspectives from Asia. The main themes in the articles of this special issue revolve around the three pillars of sustainability (economic, social, and ecological) and include urbanization, disaster, vulnerability, resource consumption, and land use. Sally Little 2015-02-20T11:47:00+00:00 2015-02-20T11:47:00+00:00 ECSA 55 Unbounded boundaries and shifting baselines: Estuaries and coastal seas in a rapidly changing world https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CLIMATE-CHANGE-IMPACTS;3e0b4dc7.1502 *Apologies for cross-posting*<br><br>Dear colleagues,<br><br>Join us at ECSA\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds next major Symposium, ECSA 55 - Unbounded boundaries and shifting baselines: Estuaries and coastal seas in a rapidly changing world, from the 6-9 September 2015 in London, UK.<br><br>ECSA 55 will bring together a global multi-disciplinary community of researchers and professionals to discuss and address issues of outstanding scientific importance in the science and management of estuaries and coastal seas. The symposium will focus on learning lessons from the past, discussing the current and forecasting for the future, spanning environmental, anthropogenic and climatic impacts on estuaries and coastal seas across the [...] Kells, Richard 2015-02-18T12:46:03+00:00 2015-02-18T12:46:03+00:00 COURSE: Longitudinal Analysis Using Stata course at Imperial College London https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CLIMATE-CHANGE-IMPACTS;dce6ab0e.1502 There are places available on the forthcoming Stata course below... Thursday, 19 February 2015 from 18:30 to 20:00 (GMT)<br>Where? The Stables, 2 Trematon Walk, Wharfdale Road, London N1 9SB<br>Today's society is on the brink of new possibilities, yet it also faces challenges and problems. Climate change is arguably the greatest of these issues, beset by the need for international co-operation on the grandest scale. Ethan Steinman 2015-02-03T14:41:46-08:00 2015-02-03T14:41:46-08:00 DVD, lectures & screenings on glacier/water link to climate change + free educational material https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CLIMATE-CHANGE-IMPACTS;fb94007b.1502 My documentary Glacial Balance (glacialbalance.com) tells the story of<br>how people across South America are dealing with climate change, and at<br>the same time, scientists studying and educating us on the importance of<br>glacial ice in the Andean tropics. My goal with the film was to<br>communicate difficult scientific concepts in understandable language and<br>to spark dialogue about the human side of climate change. [...] Oliver Hooker 2015-02-02T17:43:15+00:00 2015-02-02T17:43:15+00:00 GIS in ecological field studies COURSE https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CLIMATE-CHANGE-IMPACTS;56517574.1502 GIS course: Introduction to using GIS in ecological field studies.<br>This course will be held at SCENE (Scottish Centre for Ecology and the Natural Environment), Glasgow, United Kingdom from July 27th \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd 30th 2015<br><br>This course is aimed at biologists and ecologists who are just starting to use GIS in their ecological data collection and analysis and who have little or no existing knowledge of this subject area. We are seeking colleagues working within the fields of demography, macro-economics, local government, climate change studies and computer science who might be interested in collaborating on this exciting project. In this issue, the authors interrogate, from various angles, the relationship between knowledge, nature, and value.<br><br>Please visit the Berghahn website for more information about the journal:<br>www.journals.berghahnbooks.com/air-es [...]
